children.subject: op here: I want to clarify that I don't think Professors are out to get us, or make us miserable. I know that they want quite the opposite! Instead, I think that the student body will adapt to the amount of work assigned, which causes mental health issues in students that the Professors simply are not aware of.

A little bit on my background: I am a third year EECS major. In the past, I have struggled with mental health issues which I felt were driven both by identity issues as well as school. A while ago, my mental health improved substantially which has allowed me to reflect more seriously on the situation(s) that caused my depression/anxiety problems.

To be honest I think much of the stress within the department can be traced back to a couple faculty members who seem to think it's reasonable to ask for ~70-80 hours weekly commitment from students across all classes, if we are interested in diagnosing a cause. (all eyes on Sahai, only permitting students 30 minutes of "serenity time" per day). Obviously the competitiveness, stress of internships, etc. plays a role in the stress experienced by students, but the bulk of it stems from the above reason, in my opinion. I would argue quite strongly that the ridiculous workload exacerbates the stress of getting a job / research / internship because students have to spread themselves even more thinly to be able to achieve these. The large workload, coupled with a competitive environment, has caused a system wherein if the amount of work assigned is genuinely too much, most students will do it anyway, potentially sacrificing their mental health. This gives professors the idea that it is okay to assign this much work, when in fact it is contributing to a mental health crisis of unprecedented proportions (student mental health issues have reached an all time high, and Berkeley is worse than almost all other student bodies in this respect).

Additionally, the size of the program is so large, it creates an impersonal experience for many students, who have little to no connection whatsoever with any faculty here, leading to widespread isolation.

Releasing distributions on every single exam, project, hw, lab, etc causes students to make unnecessary comparisons with other students. I really like what EE127 is doing this semester in only releasing very rough grades (A/B/C cutoff scores) for the exam, and no distribution or statistics whatsoever. I used to (and still do to a certain extent) obsess over my standing on different assignments in the course, often staring at the distributions which were released

For my first semester ever, I am taking 3 upper division CS technical courses. This is what is required every semester of students who do not come in with any AP credit to be able to graduate in the maximum 8 semesters allotted by CoE. I'm surviving, and mentally I'm doing well also, but it is absolutely insane. (To be fair, the three techs are 127,189 and 161). Every time I finish one assignment I instantly have to turn around and finish something for another class. I find it imperative to make the point that having such insanely difficult course loads works to reinforce class boundaries between students. Wealthy students have already taken many AP courses, and can simply focus on their two technical courses per semester, whereas a poor student has to take 3 courses a semester and may have to work a part time job to support themselves financially. I don't see the workload being tamed any time soon, but I do see it as important to make this point.

I could, and probably will at a later time go on, but I'm gonna get back to studying for 189 now ;)

would be curious to hear what other students think

partial credit can be really frustrating, especially when you feel like you were 90% of the way there but cannot get partial credit due to the grading policy of the exam. It is important to realize that I think most classes would give more partial credit if they had the resources to do so for hundreds/thousands of students for every question, but they don't. Unfortunately I think with the current resources it may be too much work for the staff to grade for partial credit for certain subjects.
How do people feel about partial credit on CS exams? Is that an issue at all?

I will just share these because after listening to Dr. Raghunathan's talk and reading some of his articles, I could evaluate the zero-sum mindset (what he refers as the scarce mindset) I have built since I came to Berkeley from the third person perspective.

If you are smart, why aren't you happy? | Raj Raghunathan | TEDxDelhi

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KIp3rHn3PiI

"Why So Many Smart People Aren't Happy" Raj Raghunathan

https://getpocket.com/explore/item/why-so-many-smart-people-aren-t-happy

Dr. Paul Pearsall's "Toxic Success: How to Stop Striving and Start Thriving" might give another perspective if you struggle with some culture in Berkeley.

history.content:
These questions won't have a definitive answer, but I think, as a community, it might be helpful to have some discussion in regards to the CS culture at Berkeley.

The buzzword "CS here is toxic" has been used lately, and I think un-packaging that would be nice. We can also relate to people who respond and seek to find ways to improve the system and ourselves. At the very least, I can send this to professors i'm close with and maybe they can help change the system over time. I've discussed this topic with Professors in the past, and the ones i've talked with are very interested in making CS a better experience for students.

1. If you are stressed/overwhelmed, when does this happen(in relation to CS classes) and why?

2. Is the load of classes/clubs/research/exercise/socializing/relaxation you have too much? Is it because you're overloading on classes? Do you believe you need clubs/research to succeed in certain ways? Are you procrastinating a lot? Basically, what do you have juggling on a weekly basis and why does it cause you stress? If it does.

3. For a typical CS class, what makes it stressful? Is it the difficulty of achieving a target grade? Is it the difficulty of passing? Are specs too unclear or are homeworks and projects too hard?

4. Do you stress about not being good enough to get a job or grad school unless you get a ton of experience from courses/clubs/research? Do you think all of these activities are necessary for an undergrad to succeed in the workplace and graduate research?

5. What are some things you believe the system(CS classes or Admin) could change to make your CS experience into a less (as some people put it) "miserable" time? What are some things, you, as the individual, could do as well? For example, are class sizes hindering your experience and leading to more stress?

6. If you simply want to vent or answer some other thing, please, feel free to do so.
history.subject: Peer Questions About Stress: CS at Cal
